title: General C&P Exam Preparation Guide
meta_description: Complete guide to preparing for any VA C&P exam. Learn what to expect, how to prepare, and common mistakes to avoid.
introduction:
## What is a C&P Exam?

A Compensation and Pension (C&P) exam is a medical examination the VA uses to evaluate your disability claim. Think of it as the VA's way of measuring how your condition affects you.

**Key Facts:**
- About 93% of C&P exams are done by contractors, not VA employees
- Exams typically last 15-30 minutes
- The examiner fills out a standardized form (DBQ) about your condition
- The examiner does NOT make the final rating decision - that's done by a VA rating specialist
- What happens during this exam heavily influences your rating

**Why This Exam Matters:**
Your C&P exam can make or break your claim. The examiner's findings go directly to the rating specialist who decides your percentage. A good exam accurately captures your condition. A bad exam can result in denial or a lower rating than you deserve.
what_exam_measures:
## What the Exam Measures

During your C&P exam, the examiner fills out a DBQ (Disability Benefits Questionnaire) - a standardized form specific to your condition type.

**The DBQ Captures:**
- Current diagnosis (what you have)
- Severity of your condition
- Frequency of symptoms
- Impact on your daily life and work
- Physical measurements (for musculoskeletal conditions)
- Mental status (for psychological conditions)

**Important to Understand:**
- The examiner records findings but doesn't decide your rating
- Rating specialists use the DBQ to determine your percentage
- Each condition has specific DBQ criteria that map to rating levels
- Finding and reading your condition's DBQ beforehand helps you understand what matters

**Where to Find DBQs:**
Search 'VA DBQ [your condition]' or visit VA.gov and search for Disability Benefits Questionnaires. Reading the form shows you exactly what the examiner will document.
physical_tests:
## Physical Tests

Physical tests vary by condition type. Here's a general overview:

**Musculoskeletal Conditions (Back, Knee, Shoulder, etc.):**
- Range of motion measurements (using a goniometer)
- Strength testing
- Stability tests
- Pain point identification
- Observation of gait and movement

**Mental Health Conditions:**
- No physical tests
- Mental status examination (mood, affect, thought processes)
- Clinical interview about symptoms

**Hearing/Tinnitus:**
- Audiometry testing in a sound booth
- Otoscope examination of ears

**General Medical Conditions:**
- Varies by condition
- May include vital signs, physical exam, review of test results

**Critical Point:**
For conditions involving pain, STOP at the point where pain begins. Don't push through pain to show full range of motion - this will result in a lower rating.
questions_to_expect:
## Questions to Expect

Examiners typically ask about:

**Medical History:**
- When did your condition start?
- What caused it?
- How has it changed over time?
- What treatments have you tried?
- What medications are you taking?

**Current Symptoms:**
- How often do you experience symptoms?
- How severe are they on average?
- What makes them better or worse?
- Do you have flare-ups? How often? How long?

**Functional Impact:**
- How does this affect your daily activities?
- Can you work? What limitations do you have?
- How does it affect sleep?
- How does it affect relationships?
- What can't you do that you used to do?

**Sample Questions:**
- 'On a scale of 1-10, what's your pain level today?'
- 'How many times per week do you experience symptoms?'
- 'What activities are limited by your condition?'
- 'Have you missed work due to this condition?'
- 'Describe your worst day with this condition.'
preparation_tips:
## Preparation Tips (Before the Exam)

**2 Weeks Before:**
- Find and read the DBQ form for your condition
- Request your VA claim file if you don't have it
- Review your service treatment records

**1 Week Before:**
- Write down ALL your symptoms with frequency (daily, weekly, monthly)
- Document your WORST days, not just average days
- List all medications and treatments
- Prepare specific examples of functional limitations
- Gather any recent medical records

**Day Before:**
- Review your notes
- Prepare a written summary to bring
- Lay out comfortable, loose clothing (for physical exams)
- Get a good night's sleep

**Morning Of:**
- Eat normally
- Take your regular medications (don't skip them, don't take extra)
- Bring your written notes, medication list, and any documentation
- Arrive 15 minutes early

**What to Bring:**
- Written symptom summary
- Medication list with dosages
- Recent medical records (if not already submitted)
- List of functional limitations
- Questions you want answered
day_of_guidance:
## Day-of Guidance

**Critical DON'Ts:**
- DON'T take extra pain medication before the exam (it masks symptoms)
- DON'T push through pain during physical tests
- DON'T assume the examiner has read your file (explain everything)
- DON'T downplay symptoms to appear 'strong'
- DON'T exaggerate (hurts credibility)
- DON'T answer questions with just 'yes' or 'no'

**Critical DOs:**
- DO describe your WORST days, not just today
- DO give specific examples ('I can't lift more than 10 pounds')
- DO explain functional limitations in detail
- DO be honest and consistent
- DO stop at the point of pain during ROM tests
- DO mention ALL symptoms, even ones you think are minor
- DO bring your written notes and reference them

**Communication Examples:**
- Instead of: 'My back hurts'
- Say: 'My back pain is constant, averaging 6/10 daily. On bad days (2-3 per week), it's 8/10 and I can't get out of bed. I can't sit for more than 20 minutes, stand for more than 10 minutes, or lift anything over 10 pounds.'

- Instead of: 'I have trouble sleeping'
- Say: 'I wake up 4-5 times per night due to pain/nightmares. I average 3-4 hours of sleep. This happens every night. I'm exhausted during the day and had to reduce my work hours.'
common_mistakes:
## Common Mistakes

**Mistake 1: Minimizing Symptoms**
Military culture teaches you to 'push through.' In a C&P exam, this hurts you. Describe your condition honestly, including worst days.

**Mistake 2: Pushing Through Pain During ROM Tests**
For musculoskeletal exams, STOP where pain begins. If you push through pain, the examiner records full range of motion = lower rating. Say 'that's where pain stops me.'

**Mistake 3: Not Explaining Full Impact**
Don't just describe symptoms - explain how they affect your LIFE. What can't you do? How does it affect work? Relationships? Daily tasks?

**Mistake 4: Assuming Examiner Knows Your History**
Examiners often haven't reviewed your file. Explain everything as if they know nothing. Bring documentation and reference it.

**Mistake 5: Not Mentioning Flare-ups**
If your condition varies, describe your worst days. The examiner should estimate function during flare-ups. If they don't ask, volunteer this information.

**Mistake 6: Taking Extra Medication**
Don't mask symptoms with extra pain meds before the exam. Take your normal medications only.

**Mistake 7: Not Bringing Documentation**
Bring written notes about symptoms, medication list, and any records. Don't rely on memory alone.

**Mistake 8: Being Inconsistent**
Be honest and consistent. If you tell the examiner you can't walk, but walked into the exam normally, it hurts credibility. Describe your actual limitations accurately.
after_exam:
## After the Exam

**Immediately After:**
- Document everything that happened while it's fresh
- Write down questions asked and your answers
- Note any tests performed
- Record how long the exam lasted
- Note if anything seemed incomplete or rushed

**Getting Your Results:**
- Request a copy of the exam report through VA.gov
- Review it carefully for accuracy
- Check that the examiner documented:
  - All your reported symptoms
  - Flare-up information
  - Functional limitations
  - Accurate ROM measurements (for musculoskeletal)

**If the Exam Was Inadequate:**
- You can challenge an inadequate exam BEFORE the rating decision
- Contact your VSO or file a statement pointing out deficiencies
- Common issues: exam too short, didn't ask about flare-ups, didn't test all required areas, examiner seemed unfamiliar with condition

**Timeline:**
- C&P exam results typically go to the rating specialist within 1-2 weeks
- Overall claim decision: varies, but average is 3-4 months after exam
- You'll receive a decision letter by mail

**If You Disagree with Results:**
- You can appeal through Supplemental Claim (with new evidence)
- Higher-Level Review (if VA made an error)
- Board Appeal (for complex cases)

checklist_items.task: Find and read the DBQ form for your specific condition
Request your VA claim file if you don't have it
Review your service treatment records
Write down ALL symptoms with frequency (daily/weekly/monthly)
Document your WORST days in detail
Create a list of all medications with dosages
Write specific examples of functional limitations
Gather any recent medical records not yet submitted
Prepare comfortable, loose clothing (for physical exams)
Review your prepared notes
Take normal medications only (no extra pain meds)
Arrive 15 minutes early
Bring written notes, medication list, and documentation
Document everything immediately after exam
Request copy of exam report through VA.gov

title: PTSD C&P Exam Preparation Guide
meta_description: Complete guide to preparing for your PTSD C&P exam. Trauma-informed guidance on what to expect and how to accurately communicate your symptoms.
introduction:
## What Makes PTSD Exams Different

The PTSD C&P exam is a mental health evaluation - there are no physical tests. Instead, a psychologist or psychiatrist will ask about your trauma, your symptoms, and how PTSD affects your daily life.

**It's Okay to Not Be Okay**
We understand this exam can be difficult. Talking about trauma is hard. Many veterans feel shame or stigma about mental health. Know that:
- Your symptoms are real and valid
- Seeking help is a sign of strength, not weakness
- The examiner has heard stories like yours before
- Being honest helps you get the support you deserve

**What This Exam Determines:**
- Whether you meet diagnostic criteria for PTSD
- The severity of your symptoms
- How PTSD affects your work and relationships
- Your disability rating (0%, 10%, 30%, 50%, 70%, or 100%)

**Exam Format:**
- Conducted by a licensed psychologist or psychiatrist
- Takes 30-90 minutes depending on complexity
- Clinical interview (questions about trauma and symptoms)
- No physical tests, but examiner observes your demeanor
what_exam_measures:
## What the PTSD Exam Measures

The examiner fills out the PTSD DBQ, which evaluates:

**Diagnostic Criteria (DSM-5):**
- Exposure to traumatic event(s)
- Intrusion symptoms (flashbacks, nightmares)
- Avoidance behaviors
- Negative changes in thoughts/mood
- Hyperarousal (startle response, hypervigilance)

**Symptom Frequency and Severity:**
- How often do symptoms occur?
- How severe are they?
- How long have they lasted?

**Occupational and Social Impairment:**
This is the KEY to your rating. The VA rates PTSD based on how much it impairs your ability to work and maintain relationships:

- **0%**: Diagnosed but symptoms don't interfere with functioning
- **10%**: Mild symptoms, only during significant stress, or controlled by medication
- **30%**: Occasional decrease in work efficiency, generally functioning satisfactorily
- **50%**: Reduced reliability and productivity, difficulty with relationships
- **70%**: Deficiencies in most areas (work, family, judgment, thinking, mood)
- **100%**: Total occupational and social impairment

**Important:** The examiner documents symptoms, but your rating depends on overall impairment - how symptoms affect your actual functioning.
physical_tests:
## Mental Status Examination

There are no physical tests for PTSD. Instead, the examiner conducts a mental status examination, observing:

**Appearance and Behavior:**
- General appearance and grooming
- Eye contact
- Body language and movements
- Cooperation with the exam

**Mood and Affect:**
- Your described mood vs. observed affect
- Emotional range
- Appropriateness of emotional responses

**Thought Processes:**
- Logical and organized thinking
- Presence of delusions or hallucinations
- Insight into your condition

**Cognitive Function:**
- Concentration and attention
- Memory (short-term and long-term)
- Orientation (awareness of time, place, person)

**What This Means for You:**
The examiner is observing you throughout the interview. Be yourself - don't try to 'act' a certain way. If you're having a good day, say so. If you're anxious, that's okay. Authenticity matters more than performing symptoms.
questions_to_expect:
## Questions to Expect

**About Your Trauma (Stressor Event):**
- What happened?
- When and where did it occur?
- Were you in fear for your life or safety?
- Did you witness death, serious injury, or threat?

*Note: You may be asked to describe traumatic events. It's okay to take breaks. You can provide general information without every detail.*

**About Intrusion Symptoms:**
- Do you have nightmares? How often?
- Do you have flashbacks? What triggers them?
- Do you have intrusive memories or thoughts about the trauma?

**About Avoidance:**
- Do you avoid places, people, or activities that remind you of the trauma?
- Do you avoid talking or thinking about what happened?
- Have you lost interest in activities you used to enjoy?

**About Mood and Thinking:**
- Do you feel emotionally numb or detached?
- Do you have negative thoughts about yourself or the world?
- Do you have difficulty feeling positive emotions?
- Do you have memory problems related to the trauma?

**About Hyperarousal:**
- Do you have trouble sleeping? How many hours per night?
- Are you easily startled?
- Do you feel on edge or hypervigilant?
- Do you have angry outbursts? How often?
- Do you have difficulty concentrating?

**About Suicidal Thoughts:**
- Have you had thoughts of hurting yourself?
- Have you attempted suicide?

*This is a standard question - answering honestly won't get you in trouble. It helps document severity.*

**About Functioning:**
- Are you working? If not, why?
- How do symptoms affect your job?
- How do symptoms affect your relationships?
- Can you handle daily tasks (hygiene, errands, appointments)?
preparation_tips:
## Preparation Tips

**2 Weeks Before:**
- Find and read the PTSD DBQ (VA Form 21-0960P-3)
- Review your service records for stressor documentation
- Consider asking a trusted person to accompany you

**1 Week Before:**
- Write down ALL your PTSD symptoms
- Document frequency for each symptom (daily, weekly, monthly)
- Prepare specific examples of how symptoms affect you:
  - Work performance or inability to work
  - Relationship problems
  - Daily functioning difficulties
- Write down examples of your worst episodes

**Symptom Log Example:**
- Nightmares: 4-5 times per week
- Flashbacks: 2-3 times per week, triggered by loud noises
- Avoidance: Can't go to crowded places, stopped socializing
- Sleep: Average 3-4 hours per night
- Hypervigilance: Constant, always scanning for threats
- Anger: Outbursts 2-3 times per week, has affected marriage

**Day Before:**
- Review your notes
- Practice explaining symptoms (not memorizing a script)
- Plan comfortable clothing
- Arrange transportation

**Consider Bringing a Support Person:**
You can bring a spouse, family member, or friend for moral support. They usually wait in the lobby but can be helpful before and after.
day_of_guidance:
## Day-of Guidance

**It's Okay to Be Emotional**
This exam may bring up difficult feelings. Crying, getting upset, or needing breaks is normal and actually helps document the severity of your condition.

**Be Honest - Don't Minimize OR Exaggerate**
Describe your symptoms accurately:
- If you minimize to appear 'strong,' you'll be underrated
- If you exaggerate, it hurts credibility and may result in denial

**Describe Your WORST Days**
Don't just describe today. Explain what happens on your worst days:
- 'On bad days, I can't leave the house'
- 'During severe episodes, I dissociate for hours'
- 'At my worst, I've thought about hurting myself'

**It's Okay to Not Remember**
If you don't remember something, say 'I don't remember' rather than guessing.

**Take Breaks If Needed**
You can ask for a break if you feel overwhelmed.

**Communication Examples:**

*Instead of:* 'I have bad dreams sometimes'
*Say:* 'I have nightmares 4-5 nights per week. They're about [general description]. I wake up sweating, heart racing, and can't get back to sleep. This has been happening since [year].'

*Instead of:* 'I don't like crowds'
*Say:* 'I avoid crowded places completely. The last time I tried going to a mall, I had a panic attack - racing heart, couldn't breathe, had to leave. I haven't been to a crowded place in 2 years.'

*Instead of:* 'My marriage is struggling'
*Say:* 'My PTSD has severely affected my marriage. I have angry outbursts 2-3 times per week. My wife says I'm emotionally distant. We've talked about divorce. I can't be intimate anymore.'
common_mistakes:
## Common Mistakes

**Mistake 1: Downplaying Symptoms (Trying to Appear 'Strong')**
Military culture teaches you to minimize problems. In a PTSD exam, this results in underrating. Describe symptoms honestly, including the worst ones.

**Mistake 2: Not Mentioning All Symptoms (Shame/Stigma)**
Many veterans don't mention:
- Suicidal thoughts
- Relationship problems
- Inability to work
- Emotional numbness
- Anger issues

These are ALL relevant. Not mentioning them means they can't be considered.

**Mistake 3: Not Explaining Full Impact**
Don't just list symptoms - explain how they affect your LIFE:
- Lost jobs because of symptoms
- Divorce or relationship breakdown
- Can't maintain friendships
- Avoiding all social situations
- Unable to function some days

**Mistake 4: Forgetting Medication Side Effects**
If PTSD medications cause side effects (weight gain, sexual dysfunction, drowsiness), mention them. These affect your overall picture.

**Mistake 5: Not Preparing Specific Examples**
Vague answers hurt your claim. Prepare specific examples:
- 'Last week, I had a flashback at work and had to leave'
- 'I haven't seen my best friend in 3 years because I avoid everyone'
- 'I check the locks 10 times before bed every night'

**Mistake 6: Assuming Examiner Understands Military Culture**
The examiner may not understand terms like 'outside the wire' or military experiences. Explain clearly.

**Mistake 7: Not Mentioning Suicidal Ideation When Present**
This is critical for accuracy. If you've had suicidal thoughts, the examiner needs to know. It's a standard question and won't result in hospitalization for past thoughts.
after_exam:
## After the Exam

**Immediately After:**
- Document everything while it's fresh
- Write down questions asked and your answers
- Note how long the exam lasted
- Record if anything felt incomplete

**Getting Your Results:**
- Request a copy of the exam report through VA.gov
- Review for accuracy - did the examiner capture your symptoms?
- Check that they documented:
  - All symptoms you reported
  - Frequency and severity
  - Impact on work and relationships
  - Your worst episodes

**If the Exam Felt Inadequate:**
Common problems with PTSD exams:
- Exam was too short (should be 30-90 minutes)
- Examiner didn't ask about all symptom categories
- Examiner didn't ask about functional impairment
- Examiner seemed dismissive or didn't believe you
- Examiner didn't document your reported symptoms

**What You Can Do:**
- File a statement describing deficiencies before rating decision
- Contact your VSO for help challenging inadequate exam
- You may be entitled to a new exam

**Timeline:**
- Exam results typically sent to rating specialist within 1-2 weeks
- Overall decision: 3-4 months after exam on average
- You'll receive decision letter by mail

**If You're Struggling After the Exam:**
Talking about trauma can be difficult. If you're having a hard time:
- Veterans Crisis Line: 988 (Press 1)
- Vet Centers provide readjustment counseling
- Talk to someone you trust

Consider asking a support person to accompany you

Write specific examples of how symptoms affect work
Write specific examples of how symptoms affect relationships
